thread.title: Elisa Pierre builds on league lead over Ashley Mayhall
thread.title_full: Elisa Pierre builds on league lead over Ashley Mayhall

author: Dan Agnew
title: Elisa Pierre builds on league lead over Ashley Mayhall
text:
Elisa Pierre builds on league lead over Ashley Mayhall Pierre up by 3 strokes headed into Foothill final match on Wednesday Posted: October 13, 2015 9:12   13, 2015 9:12 p.m. West Ranch golfer Ashley Mayhall lines up a shot on the No. 3 green at TPC Valencia for the fifth Foothill League girls golf match on Tuesday. Signal photo by Katharine Lotze. Golden Valley golfer Elisa Pierre watches her ball after teeing off at the fourth hole at TPC Valencia during the fifth Foothill League girls golf match on Tuesday. Signal photo by Katharine Lotze. A A A 
It always seemed as if this year’s Foothill League girls golf Player of the Year race was destined to come down to two players. 
After playing another neck-and-neck round on Tuesday at TPC Valencia in the fifth league match of the season, all eyes will be on Golden Valley senior Elisa Pierre and West Ranch junior Ashley Mayhall headed into Wednesday's final. 
Pierre was Tuesday’s medalist with a 1-under 35, which gives the two-time defending league champion a big, three-stroke advantage over Mayhall in the overall standings. Mayhall shot a 36 on Tuesday. 
Even with just nine holes to go to stake claim to a third straight Player of the Year prize, Pierre said she doesn’t want to assume anything just yet. 
“I just want to make this a really great round because this is my last high school (league) match so I want to make this something memorable and make this something great,” said Pierre. 
Mayhall, on the other hand, comes in to the finals as a challenger with nothing to lose. 
“I just have to go out firing, and I was kind of a little tentative today so I think I just have to be a little more aggressive than I was,” the junior said. 
Her score led yet another lopsided team victory for West Ranch, which posted a 196 on the day as all five scoring golfers on the team shot 42 or better. 
After Mayhall, Kate Caffrey recorded a 37, Mack Bailey had a 39 and both Noelle Song and Adelrina Kim carded 42. 
In the league team standings, with a throw-out score factored in, West Ranch is 178 strokes ahead of the next-closest team in league, which is Valencia. 
On Tuesday, Golden Valley was second place at 246, Valencia was third with a 249, and that was followed by Saugus (266) and Canyon (280). Hart didn’t post an official team score for the day with only four golfers in action. 
Eunice Song led Valencia on the day with a 43, and Clara Venger was Saugus’ best with the same score. They were followed by Golden Valley’s Justine Reblando (44) and Valencia’s Sarah Baranda (45). 
The playoff picture is all-but set in stone on the team side. West Ranch, Valencia and Golden Valley will almost assuredly earn the automatic postseason spots as the top three finishers. 
Individually, there are still postseason spots up for grabs. 
The top six finishers in total league stroke minus a throw-out will advance. Those spots are currently occupied by Pierre, Mayhall, Bailey, Eunice Song, Caffrey and Venger. Noelle Song is three strokes back of Venger for the final spot, and Reblando is six behind.
